eli5.title: Electricity is like a moving crowd
eli5.summary: Electricity flows when tiny charges move together in a loop, like a crowd passing a message hand to hand.

blocks.title: Crowd in a hallway
blocks.text: Imagine a hallway full of people. If one person nudges forward, everyone shifts a tiny bit. Electricity is similar: charges nudge along a path, and that motion is the flow.

blocks.title: What needs to happen
items: You need a path (like a wire) for charges to move through.
You need a push (a battery) to get them moving.
The path must be a loop so the motion can continue.

blocks.title: The loop matters
blocks.text: If the loop is broken, the charges can’t keep moving, so the flow stops. That’s why a light turns off when a switch opens the circuit.

questions: What provides the push for charges to move?
Why does the path need to be a loop?

eli10.title: Electric current is moving charge
eli10.summary: Electricity flows when electric charge moves through a conductor because a voltage pushes it around a closed circuit.

blocks.text: Electric current is the movement of electric charges (mostly electrons) through a material. A battery or power supply creates a voltage that pushes these charges, and the charges drift through the circuit.

blocks.title: The ingredients
items: A conductor with free charges (like a metal wire).
A voltage source that provides an electric push.
A closed loop so charges can keep circulating.

blocks.title: Marbles on a track
blocks.text: Picture marbles on a circular track. If you push one marble, the push travels around the loop. Voltage is the push, and the moving marbles are the current.

blocks.title: Current and resistance
blocks.text: The amount of current depends on how strong the voltage is and how much resistance the material has. More resistance means less current for the same voltage.

expert.title: Charge transport driven by electric fields
expert.summary: Electric current is the net drift of charge carriers in response to an electric field established by a potential difference across a closed circuit.

blocks.title: Field-driven drift
blocks.text: A voltage source sets up an electric field along a conductor. Charge carriers acquire a small drift velocity superimposed on thermal motion, producing a net current.

blocks.explanation: Current $I$ equals carrier density $n$, charge $q$, cross-sectional area $A$, and drift velocity $v_d$.

blocks.title: Circuit continuity
blocks.text: Charge conservation requires a closed path for steady-state current. Any break produces charge accumulation, altering the local field until current stops.
Metals conduct well because of delocalized electrons; insulators lack mobile carriers under typical fields.
